title: 110_s2516
content:
The "Kendell Frederick Citizenship Assistance Act" allows the Secretary of Homeland Security to use fingerprints provided by individuals in the US Armed Forces for naturalization background checks. The "Kendell Frederick Citizenship Assistance Act" allows individuals in the US Armed Forces to apply for naturalization within 24 months of enlisting, providing biometric information to the Department of Homeland Security. The "Kendell Frederick Citizenship Assistance Act" allows US Armed Forces members to apply for naturalization within 24 months of enlisting by providing sufficient biometric information, including fingerprints, for background and security checks. Individuals can submit a new set of biometric information if it would expedite the naturalization process, with the Secretary of Homeland Security providing guidance on how to do so. The Secretary of Homeland Security, in consultation with the Secretary of Defense, determines acceptable biometric information formats, including fingerprints, for naturalization applications. The Secretary of Defense provides prints to facilitate the naturalization process and cooperates with Homeland Security. The Secretary of Homeland Security, in coordination with the Secretary of Defense and the Director of the FBI, will implement procedures for the rapid electronic transmission of biometric information for military personnel applying for naturalization. Centralization and expedited processing of naturalization applications for active-duty members of the US Armed Forces serving abroad will be ensured. SEC. 3. PROVISION OF INFORMATION ON MILITARY NATURALIZATION.
The Secretary of Homeland Security must update internet sites within 30 days of any regulation changes related to naturalization under the Immigration and Nationality Act. Congress urges necessary updates to application forms within 180 days of each effective date. SEC. 4. REPORTS.
The Secretary of Homeland Security must submit a report to congressional committees within 120 days on the adjudication process for naturalization applications, detailing the entire process from application submission to final disposition. The Secretary of Homeland Security and the Secretary of Defense must describe the methods used to handle naturalization applications, assess the effectiveness of employee supervision and training, and evaluate the use of technology to safeguard privacy. The Comptroller General and the Inspector General will conduct a study on the implementation of this Act. The Secretary of Homeland Security and the Secretary of Defense will assess technology for naturalization efficiency for members of the Armed Forces and the Act's impact on privacy and civil liberties. The Comptroller General and Inspector General will report recommendations for Act implementation improvements to the appropriate congressional committees. The Senate and House committees involved in overseeing the implementation of the Act include the Committee on Armed Services, Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs, and the Judiciary.
